messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:17): not a single reply to my e-mail to the tag
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:17): is sad
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:20): gives 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e a hug in compensation
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:20): (not that I expect 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e wants a hug, but hey)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:22): well they could at least tell me i'm being rude or something

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:23): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: The email you sent yesterday? I would have thought they'd at least need a teleconference to set an action to respond, and another to then agree on the response
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:23): aah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:23): good point
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:23): i keep forgetting that people put up artificial barriers to progress
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:38): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: OK, you win. //comment()[normalize-space(.) = 'toc'] takes 0.021s
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:38): And I don't think I'll be using anything any more complex
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:00): my display broke... now do I buy from Apple or do I shop for alternatives...
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:01): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Do you have any idea if the regexp thing actually is faster?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:02): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: I dunno. Due to the insane number of error it causes, it may well be just that which makes it slower currently
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:02): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: For a desktop machine, I assume?
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:03): I read somewhere that apple displays have poor colour saturation

4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:04): OTOH, buying displays in general is hard because the one piece of information that gives you some idea of the panel characteristics is the one that no one reveals

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:05): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: laptop actually but used like a desktop because apple doesn't have a desktop without integrated display between mini and pro
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:05): but yeah, I'm buying a desktop screen
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:05): That makes sense.
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:06): How much do you care about quality? If you care about size more than colour reproduction I expect non-Apple is the way forward. Otherwise it's a bit harder
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:11): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: Apple's actual desktop monitors are meant to be very good
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:11): But expensive.

4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:12): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I agree that they're good (and expensive). I did read somewhere that they have relatively poor colour saturation but that might not actually be true

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:12): I'd go for Dell's UltraSharp range ‚Äî¬†they use (in the 20", 24", and 30" cases) the same LCD panels as the Apple monitors, and tend to be otherwise just as good if not better, as well as being far cheaper
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:12): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: I've never seen that in any review, nor has it been my experience in the one I had :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:13): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: What they've used in the latest iMacs suffered from that, though, IIRC
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:13): I like quality but I don't need the best possible panel. at some point price and the looks of the case matter more
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:13): got an apple cinema display for his mini
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:13): and i'm very happy with it
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:13): Well I might be confused
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:13): the easy thing with apple is that you only need to pick a size
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:13): sadly the mini can't drive the biggest cinema displays, but oh well
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:13): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Well, the Apple one certainly looks better than the Dell one, though the Dell one is far from ugly.
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:14): (I ended up buying a HP LP2065 which isn't as big as I would like but has nice colours and is slightly affordable)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:14): (It looks nothing special for a monitor, but it isn't easy to find huge flaws with though)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:14): thanks. I'll look up Apple, Dell and HP
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:14): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Silly Apple not putting dual-link DVI on it!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:15): Though I doubt the onboard graphics could cope with the resolution :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:15): (we use dell ones at work, they're pretty good, lots of ports)
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:15): I /think/ I have a Dell Ultrasharp at work (an oldish 24" widescreen one) but its a little bright and hard to adjust
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:15): just re-implemented textContent for lxml: return u"".join(Element.xpath("child::text()")) :P
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:16): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: That's a more intelligent way of doing it than I thought of
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:16): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: XPath is really rather powerful. It saddens me that it doesn't support XPath 2.0, though :P

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:17): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: It's the first way I thought of doing it without manually looping over it (which I expect will be a thousandth of a second quicker)
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (00:18): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I just used recursion, which is probably slower as you have to manually check for comment nodes
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:23): There isn't even a function to lowercase a string in XPath 1.0
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:25): is @id case sensitive in HTML?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:25): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: use translate()
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:25): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Yeah, I know
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:28): Hmm, a string containing both ' and " cannot be represented in XPath 1.0
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:34): My podcast interview went well earliet
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:35): cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:35): what did you talk about?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:35): is it online yet?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:35): A lot of it was based upon the ALA article I wrote before
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:35): work around for today: xpath_string = u"concat('" + u"', \"'\", '".join(id.split("'")) + u"')"
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:36): I talked a lot about the community and empahsised that anyone can get involved with the blog, forum, mailing lists, etc.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:36): Then I discussed a few features that are available in browsers today or are being implemented
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:37): like canvas and cross document messaging
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:40): Then I did an interview with annevk about selectors api for standardssuck.org
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:44): i'm so glad y'all are doing these talks and interviews and stuff
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:45): i'd never have the time to edit the spec if i had to do it :-)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:46): oh, I got some feedback from the podcast guy...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:46): He would like to see a page maintained that describes the current state of implementations of HTML5 features
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:47): it would be good if there were someone here capable of maintaining such a page
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:47): the annotations in the spec have that info
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (00:47): There is this: http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Implementations_in_Web_browsers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:47): you could probably write a page that uses those dynamically
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:48): yeah, but the spec isn't such a friendly place to send people looking for implementation info
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): sure but i mean we could make a separate page
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): that presented the same info
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): using the same back-end protocol
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:48): Would be nice to have a basic test case for each feature so you can easily see which ones your browser supports
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): and it could even support editing the info
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): the annotation system supports listing test cases
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): and demos
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): too
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:49): what would it take to write such a page? Is there some sort of API for it?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:51): http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/toc-status.html / http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Makefile uses the API
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:52): i don't think it's documented, but yes, there's an API
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:53): cool. Anyone have time to write the script for it?
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (00:54): I might give it a go this weekend, but don't quote me on that.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:55): makes a note to quote fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 on the weekend about it.
